title: Hunt Boat Company
text:
Hunt Marine Service and Hunt Boat Company was a wooden <a href="shipbuilding">shipbuilding</a> company in <a href="Richmond%2C%20California">Richmond, California</a>. To support the <a href="World%20War%202">World War 2</a> demand for ships Ackerman Boat Company <a href="shipyard">shipyard</a> switched over to military construction and built 13 craft for the <a href="US%20Army">US Army</a> and five craft for the <a href="US%20Navy">US Navy</a>. These ships were assigned to the <a href="Pacific%20War">Pacific War</a> where they transported supplies and personnel around the <a href="Island%20hopping%20campaign">Island hopping campaign</a>. The shipyard was located at the <a href="Richmond%20Inner%20Harbor">Richmond Inner Harbor</a> in the same cannel as <a href="Kaiser%20Richmond%20No.%201%20Yard">Kaiser Richmond No. 1 Yard</a>. The address was 790 Wright Ave, Richmond on the Parr Canal. Hunt Boat Company was founded by R. J Hunt a Naval Architect. Before and after the war, Hunt built stock and custom-built speed boats and <a href="cabin%20cruiser">cabin cruiser</a>s. The stock boat was 30-foot cruiser.
Rescue Boats.
Built 42 foot <a href="Crash%20rescue%20boat">Crash rescue boat</a>s for <a href="Army%20Air%20Forces">Army Air Forces</a> Air-Sea-Rescue Boat design 221, gasoline-powered, with twin screws, built in 1943. These used two <a href="Hall-Scott">Hall-Scott</a>/<a href="Hudson_Motor_Car_Company%23World_War_II">Hudson Invader Marine Engine</a> or a <a href="Kermath">Kermath</a> Sea Ranger 6 Marine engine. This was the smallest size Rescue Boats, the large boats were 63 or 85 or 104 feet. 
Patrol boat.
Built US Army 42 foot, <a href="Patrol%20boat">Patrol boat</a>s and command boats, design 221-B, in 1944 (utility boats), same specs as Crash rescue boats:
Tugboats.
